text.loc.help.title: Help
text.loc.help.text: By moving a source around the sky you can explore how well it is location is pinpointed with the available gravitational wave detectors. How well a location is identified depends on the direction relative to the currently operating detectors. Turn them on and off, and change the source properties to see the results for yourself.
text.loc.help.about: This web-app was written and is maintained by Chris North (Cardiff University). Source code is available on GitHub.
text.loc.help.tech: The localisation results shown here make many simplifications and assumptions about the detections, so are only illustrative. The full localisation uses information about the relative amplitudes, which is nor included here. For full details of any particular detection, see the published data, which is available at the LIGO Open Science Center.

text.loc.intro.title: Welcome!
text.loc.intro.text:
Every wondered how the location of gravitational wave sources works? It's all about timing! The difference in arrival time between pairs of detectors identifies rings on the sky. More detectors means more rings, and the overlaping regions show the possible locations.

Click on the map to move the source around the sky, and turn detectors on and off.
